New Records: Shohei Ohtani became the first major league player with at least 50 home runs and 50 stolen bases in a season.
Ohtani broke the Dodgers' franchise record of 49 homers set by Shawn Green in 2001.
Ohtani became the third player in major league history with at least six hits, three homers and 10 RBIs in a game
Key Match Events: Ohtani hit three homers and stole two bases in a game, becoming the first big league player to do so.
Ohtani finished 6 for 6 with 10 RBIs in the game.
Ohtani swiped his 50th and 51st stolen bases in the first and second innings respectively.
Pre-Game Insights: Ohtani appeared to make the 50-50 mark his mission, increasing the frequency of his base-stealing attempts, and in turn his success rate went up.
Post-Match Reflections: Ohtani said he was surprised by his performance and was glad it was going well.
Ohtani's teammates have enjoyed watching him crush home runs and scamper around the bases.
Manager Dave Roberts said Ohtani is emptying the tank offensively this year.
Miscellaneous Highlights: Ohtani finished a triple shy of the cycle, adding a run-scoring single and two doubles in the game.
Ohtani was thrown out at third base while trying to stretch his second double into a triple.
The Dodgers secured a playoff spot with their 20-4 rout of the Miami Marlins.
Others: Ohtani's $700 million, 10-year deal with the Dodgers was mentioned as part of his background story.
Ohtani's elbow ligament injury was mentioned as a reason for him playing exclusively at designated hitter this season.
